newsitem.title: CUBA: OLYMPICS-CUBA'S VETERAN OLYMPIC CHIEF DIES.
newsitem.headline: OLYMPICS-CUBA'S VETERAN OLYMPIC CHIEF DIES.

text.p: Manuel Gonzalez Guerra, president for more than 30 years of Cuba's Olympic Committee and a champion of the island nation's efforts to become a world sporting power, died of a heart attack on Friday at the age of 83, state media reported.
The Cuban news agency Prensa Latina said Gonzalez had been recovering from recent heart surgery in Mexico.

The national news agency AIN called Gonzalez's death a loss for the Cuban sporting movement and for the international sports scene, noting that Gonzalez had been Cuba's representative to the International Olympic Committee (IOC).
Gonzalez had been president of the Cuban Olympic Committee since 1963 and became a member of the IOC 10 years later. He remained an honorary IOC member since 1995.
Gonzalez was a boxer in his youth and a veteran of the guerrilla struggle that brought President Fidel Castro to power in 1959. AIN called him an "exemplary revolutionary."
